meta.title: How to Stop Losing Your Sht with Your Kids
meta.subtitle: Parental meltdowns are predictable nervous system responses, not moral failures. Manage buttons through self-care and use simple pauses to regain control.

why_matters.text: Parental meltdowns are predictable nervous system responses to overload, not moral failures. By managing triggers through self-care and using simple in-the-moment pauses, parents can regain control and model emotional regulation while reducing shame and damage to the parent-child relationship.

analysis.heading: 1. Triggers vs. Button Pushers
analysis.intro_text: Children are button pushers—it is their job to test boundaries and be immature. Parents own the buttons (exhaustion, hunger, stress, history). Managing the buttons (shrinking them so they are harder to hit) is the parent's work. Blaming the child for pushing a giant, glowing red button is ineffective.

insight_card.title: Responsibility for the Buttons
insight_card.text: The child's behavior is their responsibility. Your response is yours. When you own your buttons, you reclaim your power.

analysis.heading: 2. The Myth of Multitasking
analysis.intro_text: Multitasking keeps the nervous system in a state of high alert. Single-tasking (doing one thing at a time) is presented not as productivity advice, but as a nervous system regulation strategy that directly prevents meltdowns.

insight_card.title: Single-Tasking as Self-Care
insight_card.text: The nervous system cannot be calm while juggling multiple demands. Single-tasking lowers baseline arousal, creating more space before the explosion.

analysis.heading: 3. Self-Compassion as Infrastructure
analysis.intro_text: Self-compassion isn't fluffy; it's physics. Shame increases stress, priming the nervous system to explode. Compassion lowers stress, increasing the gap between trigger and reaction.

insight_card.title: Compassion as Regulation
insight_card.text: Every moment of self-judgment narrows the window of tolerance. Every moment of self-compassion widens it.

analysis.heading: 4. "Literally Anything Else"
analysis.intro_text: The intervention strategy abandons the idea of doing the 'right' parenting move in the heat of the moment. The goal is simply to not make it worse. Doing 'literally anything else' breaks the neural pathway of the explosion.

insight_card.title: The Pause Breaks the Pattern
insight_card.text: Explosions are learned patterns of neural firing. Breaking the pattern—even with a simple action—disrupts the cascade.

actions.title: The "Notice-Pause-Do Literally Anything Else" Protocol
actions.context: Use to stop a meltdown in real-time before damage is done.

steps.description: Catch the physical 'tell'—shoulders tensing, heat rising, jaw clenching. These are your warning signs.
Stop everything. Stop moving, stop talking, just freeze.
Drink water, sit on the floor, do jumping jacks, put hands in pockets. The action breaks the neural loop.
Do not address the child until your heart rate slows and clarity returns. The damage happens in the speaking, not the feeling.

actions.title: Identifying Triggers & Tells
actions.context: Use to increase self-awareness and predict explosions before they happen.

steps.description: Multi-tasking, sensory overload, hunger, exhaustion, lack of support. Which affect you most?
What does your body do before you explode? Clenched fists? Shallow breath? 'I hate everyone' thoughts?
For one week, note what happened right before you lost it. What was the button? What was the pusher?
Was it the kid's behavior or your exhaustion? Own your piece.

actions.title: Single-Tasking Practice
actions.context: Use as a preventive strategy to lower baseline nervous system arousal throughout the day.

steps.description: Coffee, shower, dishwashing—something simple you do daily.
Phone away, TV off. Just this one thing.

steps.bold_title: Focus Entirely on the Sensory Experience
steps.description: The warmth, the smell, the sensation. Really be there.
Gently notice when you're planning or worrying, then come back to the task.
'I am just buckling the car seat.' 'I am just eating this snack.' Gradually increase throughout your day.

actions.title: The Clean Repair
actions.context: Use after you've blown up to fix the relationship and model recovery.

steps.description: Do not apologize while still angry or flooded. It won't land authentically.
'I lost my temper. That was my responsibility, not yours.'
'Next time I feel that way, I will take a break.'
Do not over-explain or beg for forgiveness. One clean repair and done.
